) IRC §
(a) requires the issuance of a release of federal tax lien within (
) calendar days of the date on which: (cid:
) The liability is satisfied; (cid:
) The liability becomes legally unenforceable; or (cid:
) A bond is accepted. (

) Generally, releases are systemically generated through the Automated Lien System (ALS) when all modules on a NFTL are satisfied on Master File Module satisfaction notices are generated by Master File whenever a module containing a TC

has been satisfied. These notices are uploaded weekly ALS and an analysis of the ALS database is completed systemically to determine if a Certificate of Release of Federal Tax Lien should be issued. (
) Occasionally, manual intervention is needed in the release process. This may occur when: (cid:
) It is determined that the release will not be systemically issued within the required thirty (
) calendar days; (cid:
) Thirty days have elapsed since the date of satisfaction and the lien has been released; (cid:
) The NFTL contains Non-Master File (NMF) modules; or (cid:
) The taxpayer, their representative, or a third party with an interest in property attached by a NFTL requests an immediate release of lien. (
) Manual intervention in the release process can take different forms. a. Manually requesting a release is the act of preparing Form

, Request for Release or Partial Release of Notice of Federal Tax Lien, forwarding it to the Centralized Lien Operation (CLO) for input to ALS. b. Manually preparing a release is the act of physically preparing Form
(Z), Certificate of Release of Federal Tax Lien, and forwarding it to CLO to be mailed to the recording office. c. Manually issuing a release is the act of physically preparing Form
(Z) and providing it directly to the taxpayer or recording office. (
) Timely release of the lien is essential. IRC §
gives taxpayers the right sue the federal government if the Service knowingly or negligently fails to release a lien. See IRM
, Civil Cause of Action Under IRC §
Failure to Release Lien. (

, Delegation Order
)) and must verify that conditions for release are met. (

) During “dead cycles” when Master File is offline for maintenance and upgrades, a release should be manually requested whenever the liability(s) the NFTL is fully satisfied. Note: Dead cycles are generally the first

cycles of the calendar year. that are received, or other satisfying transactions that occur, at the end of calendar year may have their posting to Master File delayed by the dead cycles. Releases should be manually requested for any satisfying transac- tions impacted by the dead cycles. (
) Releases are printed and mailed twice weekly by CLO. See IRM
, tralized Lien Operation, for CLO procedures. Internal Revenue Manual Cat. No.

A NFTL is considered satisfied by payment when the full amount owed of the liabilities on the NFTL, including penalties and interest, is paid. This be done by means such as a taxpayer remitting a payment; a credit offset being applied to the module(s) on the NFTL from a payment on other module(s); or the taxpayer completing the payment terms on an accepted At times, the taxpayer, their representative, or a third party with interest in property attached by the lien may request an immediate release of the This may be for the purpose of transferring property, completing some financial transaction, or just to resolve the lien. A release may be immediately issued when the liability(s) on the NFTL is satisfied by the following forms of payment: (cid:

Note: If there is reason to doubt the financial stability of an institution, then reject the tender of the institution’s guaranteed draft. If a guaranteed draft is not duly paid, then the United States will have a lien on all assets of the drawee institution in the amount of the draft. (
) When payment is made by personal check, the
calendar day release period begins after fifteen (
) calendar days from receipt. This permits sufficient time for the check to clear. A release may be issued immediately upon presentation of the canceled check.

) DO NOT issue an immediate release when credit or debit cards are used to full pay the tax liability. Credit and debit cards are barred for immediate Credit of lien because of the possibility of chargeback of such payments over a period of months. It is unlikely that a release will be requested from a credit debit card payment because the Service may accept such payments only within three years after assessment. However, if a debit or credit card is accepted to satisfy a tax year and a request for release is received, the lien may not be released until the period for chargeback has run. Due to the chance of reversal, the release should not be issued until the pending status of the payment is resolved. Payment information is generally available on IDRS within

hours after the settlement date. A certificate of release may be issued when full payment of the liability is by an electronic funds transfer (EFT), such as Direct Pay, and the payment has fully posted to IDRS (i.e., no longer pending). Due to the chance of reversal, the release should not be issued until the pending status of the payment is resolved. Payment information is generally available on IDRS within

hours after the settlement date. Transaction returns and reversals generally appear a day later, but may not appear for up to five business days. Similar to releases for personal checks, if the taxpayer can provide proof of payment (generally in the form of an acknowledgement number the taxpayer received from EFTPS when they made their deposit), the release can be issued while the payment is pending on IDRS.

) Certificate issuance should be approved prior to ALS input. Therefore, documents can be generated and mailed without contacting the functional manager. (

) NFTLs filed on Form

(Y)(c), Notice of Federal Tax Lien, show a “Last for Refiling.” Language on the form states that if the NFTL is not refiled by Lien date, the lien shall be considered to be released. This is known as a self- releasing lien. Note: The self-releasing language was incorporated into Form
(Y) in

In very rare situations, you may encounter a NFTL filed prior to that time. Although such a NFTL would not have been self-releasing, it still required timely refiling to maintain its effectiveness. Any such NFTLs that continue to be identified as active by the local recording office should be searched and addressed accordingly. (
) The primary reason for the self-releasing statement is to provide an efficient means to notify third parties that the lien is no longer enforceable. The self- release clause meets the
-day requirement to release a lien. When the Day for Refiling” passes and no refile has been done, both the statutory lien and the NFTL are immediately released. (

If the taxpayer requests a certificate of release and the underlying ties have been satisfied or are no longer enforceable, then a certificate release should be issued. b. A certificate of release must be issued for a when the CSED expires. (
) A NFTL refiled on Form
(F), Notice of Federal Tax Lien Refile, is not releasing. A certificate of release must be filed when the liability becomes unenforceable or is otherwise satisfied. (

, Notice of Lien Refiling. (
) After a NFTL is filed, an amended NFTL might be filed to correct an error on the NFTL and/or the NFTL might be refiled to extend its life. See IRM Related NFTL Corrections, and IRM
, Notice of Lien Refiling. Also, in certain cumstances, a another NFTL might be filed based on the statutory liens covered by the NFTL (e.g., NFTL in another location, special condition (

) The issuance of a certificate of release for the original NFTL extinguishes statutory lien(s) covered by the NFTL and invalidates any related filings; however, it is IRS’ general policy to issue a certificate of release for each related filing when the underlying liability is satisfied. (

) When there are related filings to a satisfied NFTL, ensure certificates of release are issued for the related filings as appropriate. Reminder: It is possible for a certificate of release to be issued for a NFTL without the original NFTL being released. For instance, there are six assessments on the original NFTL but only four of the assessments were subject to, and included on, the refile. If the four assessments the refile are satisfied but the other two on the original NFTL are still due, only the NFTL refile should be released.

It is possible for a certificate of release to be issued for a NFTL refiling without the original NFTL being released. For instance, there are six assessments on the original NFTL but only four of the assessments were subject to, and included on, the refile. If the four assessments on the refile are satisfied but the other two on the original NFTL are still due, only the NFTL refile should be released.

Neither the IRC nor Treasury regulations address the method in which lien cer- tificates are to be signed; however, they both address the Secretary’s authority to develop procedures associated with the use and acceptability of electronic signatures on forms and other documents. Approval of documents must always be in accordance with IRM
, Del- egation Order
(Rev.
).. Certificates, letters, and forms related to liens may be signed by the approving official via electronic means or by authorized stamp when a physical signature is not feasible.

) Certificates, letters, and forms related to liens may be signed by the official via electronic means or by authorized stamp when a physical is not feasible. Note: Documents generated by ALS are digitally signed in accordance with the egation order. The electronic signature described in this section is only for situations where manually-prepared certificates are needed. (

) To sign a document electronically, the document must be converted to a Portable Data Format (PDF) using Adobe Acrobat and the approving official must create a signature file. The format of the electronic signature should adhere to the following: a. The signature should not contain the email address, logo, location or unnecessary information. b. The signature should preferably be an actual/graphic signature file of approving official or at the minimum should show the name of the approving official. It should not be the Standard Employee Identifier as that is for internal use only. c. The approving official should validate the signature so that the pdf question mark does not appear. (

) Approval must be granted on a case by case basis. The ICS history must documented by the approving official to indicate the electronic or facsimile signing of the lien certificate and associated correspondence. (

When requesting a new NFTL, the updated CSED should be specified for assessment to be included on the new NFTL. The amount to be shown on the new NFTL should be the total balance due the time of filing the new NFTL. The new NFTL does not have to contain only the tax periods that were on released lien. Any tax periods eligible for NFTL filing can be included on new NFTL. It is not necessary to file the new NFTL in the same recording office where revocation document was filed. The new NFTL should be filed in a place propriate for the current location of the taxpayer and/or their assets. The filing of the new NFTL must occur after the filing of the revocation. If new NFTL is filed before the revocation, the NFTL is not valid. It should be withdrawn as an improper filing and another, new NFTL filed.

* Pursuant to IRC 6325, the thirty day time frame to release a lien is required in those situations where the liability is fully satisfied or has become legally unenforceable, or a bond is accepted for the collection of the liability. In other situations where these conditions are not met (e.g., bankruptcy discharge), the time frame to release a lien is a matter of policy. For example:
